author: By Cecilia Kang and Natasha Singer
title: Meta Accused by States of Using Features to Lure Children to Instagram and Facebook
description: More than three dozen states and the District of Columbia accused the tech giant of knowingly using addictive features to draw in and retain children and teenagers.
content: Meta was sued by more than three dozen states on Tuesday for knowingly using features on Instagram and Facebook to hook children to its platforms, even as the company said its social media sites were safe for young people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Polish Bishop Resigns After Diocese Is Rocked by Sex Scandal
description: A priest in the bishop’s diocese was accused of holding a sex party in his church apartment that involved a male prostitute who lost consciousness.
content: A Polish bishop whose diocese has been badly tarnished by reports of a gay orgy involving priests and a prostitute resigned on Tuesday, the latest in a long series of sexual and financial scandals in Poland’s Roman Catholic Church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: She Made Pesto. People Started Spilling Their Secrets.
description: Call us crazy if you want, but a TikTok star who made pesto instead of buying it inspired countless confessionals that had nothing to do with cooking.
content: Susi Vidal, a TikTok creator, makes pesto regularly for weeknight meals. She always has pasta on hand, and while she frequently posts videos of more elaborate creations like sun-dried tomato focaccia and ratatouille, more often than not she just wants a bowl of noodles with sauce for dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Wednesday Briefing: Gaza Death Toll Climbs
description: Plus remembering Park Seo-Bo and his art.
content: The Israeli military said yesterday that it had stepped up its bombardment of Gaza, where Palestinian officials said that hundreds of people had been killed. Diplomatic pressure grew for Israel to delay its ground invasion of the enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Louis Vuitton Strikes Another Major Deal in Sports
description: The luxury brand will sponsor the prestigious America’s Cup yacht race in 2024 — the same year it sponsors the Olympics.
content: Louis Vuitton’s takeover of the sporting world continues apace: Next August, shortly after the LVMH-sponsored Summer Olympic Games end in Paris, the Louis Vuitton-sponsored America’s Cup will begin in Barcelona.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Shapiro
title: Why My Fall Made Me Feel So Ashamed
description: If we could acknowledge that we are all vulnerable, our shame would go away.
content: The morning after I fell, I lay in bed assessing the damage. My knees were banged up. The right one was painful and swollen. I felt for the bandage my husband had secured around my chin the night before. It was still in place, sticky with blood. My jaw ached. I ran my tongue along my teeth; none seemed to be broken. A near miss, I thought. Disparate verses from one of my favorite poems, by Wislawa Szymborska, looped through my mind: It could have happened. It had to happen. It happened, but not to you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: ‘Elephant’ at 20: A Drama About a Mass Shooting Remains Chilling
description: When Gus Van Sant made his experimental feature in response to the 1999 Columbine High School shooting, he said, he didn’t envision a future America with “an endless number of shootings.”
content: For a long time, after each new mass shooting, the actor Alex Frost would guiltily ponder whether the first movie he ever appeared in may have motivated the perpetrators. Frost played one of the gunmen in Gus Van Sant’s unflinching look at adolescent life, “Elephant,” when he was only 15 years old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Macron Says Israel Must Fight Hamas ‘Without Mercy but Not Without Rules’
description: The French president also suggested that the international coalition once deployed to fight the Islamic State could also fight Hamas.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France expressed firm support for Israel during a trip there on Tuesday, even as he insisted that its war against Hamas should spare civilians and that Israel should not lose sight of a political resolution to the decades-long Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Palestinian Republic of Fear and Misinformation
description: As in any tyrannical or fanatical regime, Palestinians who stray from the approved line put themselves at serious risk.
content: Many years ago, when I first started covering the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, I got to know a gifted Palestinian journalist who, for reasons that will become apparent in a moment, I’ll refer to only by his first name, Said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Donald Trump and Christian Nationalism
description: Responses to a column by David French. Also: The Georgia plea deals; a sniper in Ukraine; protecting the innocent in Gaza; marathon helpers.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Light Spray
description: Daniel Grinberg is driven by a single-minded love of Halloween.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: How to Enforce a Landmark Pollution Law? It’s Complicated.
description: Regulators are putting the finishing touches on Local Law 97, which takes effect next year, and aims to restrict greenhouse gases from buildings.
content: Environmental activists appeared in droves on Tuesday at an online public hearing in New York to voice concerns that the enforcement of a new climate law that aims to limit pollution from large buildings would be too lenient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Lowenstein
title: Is the American Dream More Dead Than Alive?
description: In “Ours Was the Shining Future,” the New York Times writer David Leonhardt dissects the country’s record on prosperity, arguing that progressive policies are best suited for achieving our ideals.
content: David Leonhardt, a senior writer for The New York Times, has written a “biography” of the American dream, specifically — as his title, “Ours Was the Shining Future,” suggests — an account of how the dream has withered and all but died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rich Lowry
title: How the Right’s Purity Tests Are Haunting the House G.O.P.
description: The question for House Republicans is: Does anybody here want to play this game?
content: When Casey Stengel had the misfortune to be the manager of the historically inept 1962 New York Mets, his famous plaint was, “Can’t anybody here play this game?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Finds the House Speaker Pool Lacking in Diversity
description: Stephen Colbert named actual candidates for the job before switching to made-up politicians — “and literally no one knows when I did, including me.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Joy Dong
title: ‘Honest Mistake,’ Says U.S. Politician Arrested on Gun Charge in Hong Kong
description: A Washington state senator, Jeff Wilson, said he discovered the pistol on his flight and notified customs officials at the Hong Kong airport.
content: A Washington state senator was arrested at a Hong Kong airport and spent days in custody on charges of possessing a locally unregistered firearm, his office said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Borrowers Start to Process High Rates Won’t Fall Soon
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 23, 2023.
content: “If you go around and talk to developers about ‘Hey, what’s your next project?’ it’s crickets.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: The ‘Devil’s Playground’ of Urban Combat That Israel Is Preparing to Enter
description: A ground invasion in Gaza could produce some of the fiercest street-to-street fighting since World War II.
content: Heavy fire from rooftops and booby-trapped apartments. Armor-piercing projectiles blowing up troop carriers. Fighters blending in with civilians, launching drone ambushes, or surging from tunnels full of enough ammunition, food and water to sustain a long war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ben Protess and Kate Christobek
title: Cohen Denounces Trump During Courtroom Face-Off
description: Michael D. Cohen accused his onetime boss, Donald J. Trump, of manipulating his net worth as Mr. Trump stared blankly ahead. It was their first interaction in five years.
content: For five years, Michael D. Cohen has waged battle with Donald J. Trump from afar: on social media, on cable television and in the pages of his books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A Fall-Themed Menu for Australia’s State Dinner
description: Because of what the first lady called “tumultuous times,” the White House canceled a plan to have the B-52s perform, inviting the musicians as guests instead. Root vegetables will be featured at the table.
content: The fourth state dinner hosted by the Biden administration, to honor Anthony Albanese, the prime minister of Australia, will feature a menu of fall vegetables, a backdrop of florals and a selection of instrumental music performed by military bands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Watchdog Says Trump Didn’t Influence Decision on F.B.I. Headquarters
description: Still, the bureau’s director noted that Donald J. Trump had made it unmistakably clear, even before appointing him, that he wanted the F.B.I. to stay where it was.
content: The Justice Department’s inspector general found no evidence that President Donald J. Trump had improperly pressured the F.B.I. to rebuild its headquarters on its current site, the crumbling J. Edgar Hoover Building in Washington, according to a report released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: What to Know About Dengue Fever as Cases Spread to New Places
description: Dengue, the excruciating mosquito-borne disease, is surging throughout the world and coming to places that had never had it. California just confirmed a rare U.S. case.
content: Cases of dengue fever, a mosquito-borne viral illness that can be fatal, are surging around the world. The increase is occurring both in places that have long struggled with the disease and in areas where its spread was unheard-of until the last year or two, including France, Italy and Chad, in central Africa. Last week, health officials in Pasadena, Calif., reported a first case of locally transmitted dengue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Families of Hostages Gather in New York to Pressure the United Nations
description: Relatives of those being held in Gaza rallied outside U.N. headquarters on Tuesday.
content: In Dag Hammarskjöld Plaza, just steps away from the United Nations headquarters, pro-Israel demonstrators on Tuesday laid out some 200 pairs of shoes — one for each person held hostage by Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Clean Energy’s Powerful Momentum
description: Peak fossil fuel use may be only a few years away.
content: Nearly every day, there is confounding news to make us question whether the world is pushing hard enough to transition away from fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Panera Bread’s ‘Charged Lemonade’ Is Linked to Death in Lawsuit
description: The lemonade has as much caffeine as an energy drink, but does not reflect that in its marketing, according to a lawsuit. A student with a heart condition died after drinking it, her parents say.
content: A college student with a heart condition died after she drank a heavily caffeinated drink from Panera Bread, likely thinking it had a safe amount of caffeine, her parents said in a lawsuit filed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Carving Pumpkins
description: How do you celebrate Halloween?
content: It’s spooky season. Do you look forward to this time of year? If so, what do you like about it? If not, why not?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Snap Reports 5% Revenue Increase, Reversing Declines in Growth
description: The social media company posted rising sales after two quarters of declines, but added that the ad market remains unpredictable.
content: Snap, the parent company of Snapchat, on Tuesday reported that its revenue rose 5 percent in the latest quarter after two straight quarters of declines, as the digital advertising market rebounded.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘You Have Me Now’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: I watched the car on the ride-hailing app circle my block three times. When the driver finally arrived, he said the GPS was wonky. Frustrated, I erred on the side of patience and guided him down Atlantic Avenue, then Flatbush, onto the Manhattan Bridge. As the city fanned out in front of us, he said, “Wait, we’re going to Manhattan?” “Yeah, Soho.” Our eyes locked in the mirror. He laughed. “I’ve never been to Manhattan!” He had only lived here two weeks, and I felt a spark of happiness, witnessing someone else bewitched by the city for the first time. — Marti Trgovich
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisy Lafarge
title: A New, Feminist Retelling of ‘1984’
description: Authorized by the Orwell estate, “Julia,” by Sandra Newman, revisits the events of the dystopian classic, this time as seen by Winston Smith’s love interest.
content: At the outset of “Julia” — Sandra Newman’s retelling of George Orwell’s classic “1984,” this time as seen by Winston Smith’s love interest, Julia — we learn that our protagonist is a mechanic in the Fiction Department. Fiction, along with Records and Research, makes up the Ministry of Truth, which is responsible for producing the official narrative of Oceania, and, since Oceania is a totalitarian state, producing history itself. While Orwell situated Winston in Records, altering past news articles, Newman has Julia crawling around within the systems of Fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Alford
title: Under the Leather Jackets: Anxiety, Bravado and the Keys to TV Stardom
description: Candid memoirs by Henry Winkler and John Stamos reveal how lucky breaks — and Yale training, and a curling iron — made them into household names.
content: When I worked for a casting director in the 1980s, the most fun part of the job was looking at the marked-up appointment sheet at the end of each day. Because film and TV auditions are intimate, often conducted over a desk, my boss had devised a code by which to secretly rate the sensitive actors sitting just inches away from her: CBNC (close but no cigar), LLIT (a little long in the tooth), and so on.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 24, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Oct. 24, 2023.
content: An article on Thursday about the impact of voting rights legislation on the governor’s race in Mississippi misstated the status of a law that had stripped voting rights from people convicted of a range of felonies in Mississippi. While a court had overturned the law in August, that decision was vacated and an appeal is currently pending; it is not the case that the law has fallen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The Jewish Left Is Trying to Hold Two Thoughts at Once
description: Spencer Ackerman and Peter Beinart navigate the tensions between grief and solidarity in the aftermath of Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack.
content: Grief moves slowly, and war moves quickly. After Hamas assailants killed at least 1,400 Israelis and took hundreds more hostage, Israel dropped more than 6,000 bombs on Gaza in the first week of a conflict that is ongoing. So far, more than 5,000 Palestinians are reported dead and many more injured. There’s no one way to cover this that reconciles all that is happening and all that needs to be felt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: ‘It’s Like Our Country Exploded’: Canada’s Year of Fire
description: Endless evacuations, unimaginable smoke and heat, 45 million acres burned — is this the nation’s new normal?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: Clean Energy, Cherished Waters and a Sacred California Rock Caught in the Middle
description: The proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary could create a new model for Native co-management of public lands. But the sanctuary faces headwinds with a last-minute boundary change to accommodate a wind farm.
content: My paddle slips gently through calm ocean water as the kayak glides toward the mouth of Morro Bay Harbor. I approach a sandbar covered in resting cormorants, as sea otters float in nearby kelp, inky-eyed pups nestled on their mothers’ chests. On this windless morning, the marine layer paints the world in a gentle watercolor wash. In front of me, Morro Rock rises dramatically from the landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Microsoft’s A.I. Investment Stabilizes Its Cloud Business
description: Revenue increased 13 percent in the latest quarter compared with a year earlier. Profit rose 27 percent.
content: Microsoft on Tuesday reported strong sales in its latest quarter, showing that its corporate customers have been shaking off jitters about spending heavily in the uncertain economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Kate Kelly
title: Is E.S.G. Falling Out of Favor?
description: Chevron’s $53 billion bid for Hess may drive consolidation in the oil patch. Meanwhile, investors are pulling back from climate-focused investment products.
content: To oil analysts and investors, Chevron’s $53 billion takeover of Hess confirmed that there’s a new cycle of consolidation in the industry, coming less than two weeks after Exxon Mobil’s $59.5 billion bid for Pioneer Natural Resources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Men Accused of Stealing 2 Million Dimes Face Federal Charges
description: The four-man crew took the coins from a truck that had left the U.S. Mint in Philadelphia, prosecutors say. They are also accused of stealing liquor, appliances and frozen food in other heists.
content: Earlier this year, several things went missing from cargo trucks in Philadelphia. Six refrigerators. Sixty cases of Jose Cuervo tequila. And then, somehow, more than two million dimes, worth nearly a quarter of a million dollars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Black Sabbath Ballet Turns Up the Volume on a Varied London Season
description: The fall dance calendar began with English National Ballet under new leadership. Then came Royal Ballet’s “Don Quixote” and “Black Sabbath: The Ballet.”
content: As the crowds filed out of Sadler’s Wells theater on Friday, I approached a bushy-bearded man in a leather jacket and Black Sabbath T-shirt. Was he a die-hard aficionado of the heavy metal band? He was. What had he thought of the show we had just seen, “Black Sabbath: The Ballet”? “Fantastic!” he said, beaming. “But I’m also a big ballet fan. I was at ‘Don Quixote’ at the Royal Opera House last week.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: With Rent Out of Reach, a Back Seat Becomes a Bedroom
description: For a Times journalist, months of reporting led to surprising discoveries about the growing number of Americans who, amid a nationwide housing crisis, live in their cars.
content: In August, when Rukmini Callimachi, a New York Times reporter who covers real estate, pulled into a parking lot in Kirkland, Wash., that’s dedicated to people who live in their cars, she expected to see clunkers, perhaps with bent fenders or a few broken windows protected by cardboard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Alejandro Cegarra
title: Jamaica Fears Brain Drain as Teachers Leave for U.S. Schools
description: Severe teacher shortages in the United States are prompting schools to recruit foreign teachers, sparking fears that education in Jamaica will suffer.
content: Okeef Saunders loves his job teaching history to high school students in Jamaica’s capital. But he is getting ready to leave for the United States, where a teaching job with a much bigger paycheck in North Carolina awaits him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Reese
title: A Book Critic as Wild for Food as He Is for Literature
description: “The Upstairs Delicatessen,” a memoir by Dwight Garner of The New York Times, traces his life’s twin passions.
content: Pity the freelancer tasked with reviewing for The New York Times the intimate and joyful new memoir by the esteemed Times book critic Dwight Garner. Unqualified praise in these pages for “The Upstairs Delicatessen: On Eating, Reading, Reading About Eating, and Eating While Reading” will never be entirely trusted. Fortunately, after my third reading of Garner’s eccentric bricolage of literary anecdote and autobiography, I did come up with a few qualifications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: K-Pop Group Celebrates Wrong Rangers at Texas Show
description: Members of the band STAYC performed in Dallas last week in the jerseys of the Rangers, the Glaswegian soccer club, rather than the Rangers, the World Series-bound Texas baseball team.
content: It’s a longstanding concert tradition: A band comes to town for a show and performs a few songs while wearing the jerseys of a local sports team. The goal is to milk some good will and (cheap? you decide) applause from the fans on hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, Ghost Influencer
description: Almost 25 years after her tragic death, the lithe blonde is the muse of the season.
content: When John F. Kennedy Jr.’s plane crashed on July 16, 1999, killing both Mr. Kennedy and his wife, Carolyn Bessette Kennedy (as well as Carolyn’s older sister), at the peak of their glamour and celebrity, the couple became not just another tragic story, but a symbol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: On the Agenda for Australia’s State Visit: China, Trade and a U.S. Marine Band
description: President Biden will welcome Anthony Albanese, the prime minister of Australia, for meetings and a state dinner in Washington.
content: Five months ago, President Biden canceled a trip to Australia because the United States was on the brink of defaulting on its debt, and it seemed like a bad time to be out of town. Then he extended an invitation to Anthony Albanese, the prime minister of Australia, for a state visit in Washington — a redo of sorts, when things would be calmer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: Behind a Proposal to Create a Marine Sanctuary Along California’s Central Coast
description: The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would be a tribal-led effort that would protect more than 7,500 square miles on and offshore.
content: The scent of sage and the sounds of a traditional Chumash song filled the air on a recent gray afternoon in Morro Bay. Waves crashed against a nearby breakwater as Morro Rock, a 576-foot volcanic plug, loomed dramatically behind us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: ‘I Went Through Hell,’ Freed Israeli, 85, Says of Subterranean Captivity in Gaza
description: Yocheved Lifshitz, a grandmother and Israeli peace activist, was kidnapped, beaten and held in tunnels built by Hamas for 17 days.
content: In harrowing detail, an 85-year-old Israeli grandmother described her 17-day ordeal as a hostage, offering for the first time a captive’s account of the armed Palestinian group Hamas’s subterranean garrison beneath Gaza, the conditions in which the group’s hostages are being held and the operatives deployed to tend to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks and Derek Arthur
title: We’re Disconnected and Lonely. David Brooks Has a Solution.
description: Become such a good listener, you’re “burning calories.”
content: When the Opinion columnist David Brooks was growing up, he was emotionally detached, he says. Over the past several years, he’s worked to change that. In this audio essay, Brooks shares what he learned opening up with others on his journey to become a fuller human being: that better conversation could help save America from its “social and emotional breakdown.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Millennials and Gen Z Are Tilting Left and Staying There
description: Younger voters may get more conservative as they age, but that doesn’t mean they will become Republicans.
content: There is an old saying that if you’re not a liberal when you’re young, then you have no heart, and if you’re not a conservative when you’re old, you have no brain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carolina Abbott Galvão
title: María José Llergo’s Songs Have Flamenco Roots. They Raise a Ruckus.
description: This Spanish singer’s debut, “Ultrabelleza,” experiments with a signature genre of her Andalusian homeland, creating an unexpected homage.
content: When the Spanish singer María José Llergo talks about flamenco, it often sounds as though she is describing something springing from beneath her feet. “The genre is rooted in my land,” she said, in a video call from her place just outside Madrid. “It’s in our roots.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel E. Gross
title: How Aid in Dying Became Medical, Not Moral
description: The debate over aid in dying still rages in the language that medicine and the media use to describe the practice.
content: In rural Iowa, Peg Sandeen recalls, living with AIDS meant living under the cloud of your neighbors’ judgment. After her husband, John, fell ill in 1992, the rumors began swirling. The couple had almost learned to live with the stigma when things took a turn for the worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Reviving the American Dream
description: The American political system helped create today’s problems, and only the American political system can solve them.
content: Many Americans have come to see the political system as rigged. They worry that grass-roots political movements are powerless to overcome entrenched interests, whether those interests are self-serving politicians, large employers or dominant social media platforms. And I understand why this cynicism exists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Several People Hospitalized in Austria After Taking Suspected Fake Ozempic
description: The drug, used to treat diabetes, has become popular as a weight loss treatment. Now, officials are warning of counterfeit versions circulating in Europe.
content: Several people in Austria were treated in a hospital after using what government officials believe to be counterfeit Ozempic, underscoring worries across parts of Europe that fake versions of the diabetes drug may be circulating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: To Star at the Venice Biennale, Artists Need Patrons’ Deep Pockets
description: Jeffrey Gibson, the Indigenous artist representing the United States in April, must rely on patchwork private support. The promise of government sponsorship has not kept pace with rising costs.
content: When organizers with the State Department announced that Jeffrey Gibson would represent the United States at the 60th Venice Biennale next spring — the contemporary art world’s version of the Olympics — there were clear reasons to celebrate. Not only would the artist fulfill a personal dream, he would also be writing a chapter of American history as the first Indigenous artist to receive a solo exhibition there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: A Third Speaker Nominee Failed to Unify Republicans
description: Also, Israel intensified its airstrikes in Gaza. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: House Republicans voted this afternoon to nominate Tom Emmer — a Representative from Minnesota who holds the No. 3 leadership post — to be the chamber’s next speaker. But within hours, he dropped his bid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Pilot Who Disrupted Flight Said He Had Taken Psychedelic Mushrooms, Complaint Says
description: In an interview with the police, the off-duty Alaska Airlines pilot also said he thought he was having a nervous breakdown and had not slept for more than 40 hours, according to a criminal complaint.
content: An off-duty Alaska Airlines pilot who tried to shut off the engines during a flight on Sunday told investigators that he had been sleepless and dehydrated since he consumed psychedelic mushrooms about 48 hours before boarding and that he had been depressed for a long time, state and federal court documents said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: New Normal or No Normal? How Economists Got It Wrong for 3 Years.
description: Economists first underestimated inflation, then underestimated consumers and the labor market. The key question is why.
content: Economists spent 2021 expecting inflation to prove “transitory.” They spent much of 2022 underestimating its staying power. And they spent early 2023 predicting that the Federal Reserve’s rate increases, meant to cure the inflation, would plunge the economy into a recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: China Dismisses Defense Minister Amid Swirl of Speculation
description: The unexplained dismissal of Gen. Li Shangfu, the military’s top diplomat, came shortly after the foreign minister and two top commanders in the country’s rocket forces were also ousted.
content: Just four months ago, China’s defense minister, Gen. Li Shangfu, was at a forum for regional officials in Singapore, serving as the face of his country’s bold vision for reshaping Asia’s balance of power. He cast China as a force for stability and accused the United States of stirring trouble in the region, suggesting that its leaders should “mind your own business.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: Want a Viral TikTok? Put On Some Lip Gloss.
description: It’s one of many subtle tactics used by social media stars to make you stop and look.
content: If this story were a TikTok video, the writer would be applying lip gloss right about … now. Unscrewing the cap on a tube of mauve goo and giving it a generous swipe across puckered lips. Mwah!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: In Tight G.O.P. Primary in Ohio, Newt Gingrich Picks His Candidate
description: Three Ohio Republicans are competing in the Senate primary. Mr. Gingrich is backing Bernie Moreno, a businessman who is a relative political newcomer.
content: The Senate race in Ohio is one of the best chances for Republicans to capture a seat from Democrats next year. But first, the Republican Party has to survive a three-way primary without damaging its increasingly strong brand in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Despite State Bans, Legal Abortions Didn’t Fall Nationwide in Year After Dobbs
description: The first full-year census of U.S. abortion providers shows significant increases in abortion in states where it’s legal.
content: In the year after the Supreme Court ended the constitutional right to abortion, something unexpected happened: The total number of legal abortions in the United States did not fall. Instead, it appeared to increase slightly, by about 0.2 percent, according to the first full-year count of abortions provided nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Michael Crowley
title: White House Says a Cease-Fire Would Only Benefit Hamas
description: A White House spokesman said the administration supported humanitarian pauses to allow aid to reach Gaza and civilians to evacuate.
content: The United States on Tuesday rejected growing calls to support a cease-fire in the war between Israel and Hamas because such a move would only benefit Hamas, a White House spokesman said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Amid Intense Fighting, Ukraine Orders Evacuation of Children
description: The evacuations from villages near the front line underscored the ferocity of the fighting as both Ukraine and Russia press bloody assaults.
content: The Ukrainian government has ordered the evacuation of hundreds of children in shattered villages across southern Ukraine, and is sending police door to door to convince parents that it is time to escape the widespread Russian shelling in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Neal E. Boudette
title: U.A.W.’s Expanding Strikes Could Signal an Endgame or a Long Struggle
description: The United Automobile Workers on Tuesday expanded its strike to General Motors’ largest U.S. plant a day after striking at a Ram truck plant.
content: The United Automobile Workers union shut down production at General Motors’ largest U.S. factory on Tuesday, significantly stepping up pressure on the large U.S. automakers as signs multiplied that the six-week strike is taking a toll on profits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Jaffe Ramis
title: Stop, Before You Close This Tab (or Any Others) …
description: Think of your browser like an ongoing autobiography. Why would you ever delete it?
content: Whenever my computer freezes and shuts down, I’m not surprised. I have a tab problem. As I’m writing this, I currently have 72 browser tabs open: my email, my calendar, the dinner menu of the restaurant where I’m meeting a friend tonight, directions for how to get there, an order confirmation for a refill of Sonicare toothbrush heads, my local yoga studio’s weekly schedule, medical claims forms, Ina Garten’s lemon orzo recipe to make this weekend. My phone, meanwhile, has no fewer than 263 open tabs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Who is Tom Emmer, the latest Republican nominee for speaker?
description: Mr. Emmer, the No. 3 Republican in the House, has pitched himself as a unity candidate, but some hard-right Trump supporters have said he was not supportive enough of the former president.
content: House Republicans on Tuesday elected Representative Tom Emmer of Minnesota, the No. 3 in the party, as their speaker nominee after five rounds of ballots that pointed to a precarious path forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump Files More Motions to Derail Federal Jan. 6 Case
description: The former president’s lawyers made a series of arguments seeking dismissal of the federal charges that he conspired to overturn the 2020 election.
content: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump fired off a barrage of new attacks on Monday night against the federal charges accusing him of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, filing nearly 100 pages of court papers seeking to have the case thrown out before it reaches a jury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Democratic Group Steps Up Warnings Over a No Labels Third Party Bid
description: A Third Way memo cites a recent polling presentation from a centrist organization, No Labels, which shows a hypothetical ticket scrambling the presidential race.
content: The Democratic group Third Way has released a new broadside against the No Labels effort to field a third-party presidential ticket in 2024, citing a recent polling presentation that shows a hypothetical ticket scrambling a race between President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M. Profit Down 7% in Strike-Affected Quarter
description: The carmaker said the six-week strike by the United Automobile Workers union had cost it $800 million so far and could cost $200 million for every week it continued.
content: General Motors said on Tuesday that it made $3.1 billion in profit from July through September, a year-over-year decline of more than 7 percent that was partly due to the six-week strike by the United Automobile Workers union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: After Outcry, Writers Guild Tries to Explain Silence on Hamas Attack
description: The union said it had made no public statement because “we are American labor leaders, aware of our limitations and humbled by the magnitude of this conflict.”
content: Facing mounting pressure from more than 300 Hollywood screenwriters questioning why it had not publicly condemned the Hamas attack on Israel this month, the Writers Guild of America West sent a letter to its members on Tuesday that sought to explain its silence while also calling the attack “an abomination.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Freda Kreier
title: See You Later, Not-an-Alligator
description: Caimans are an invasive species in Florida, where they ran wild over half a century ago. Researchers known as the Croc Docs may be close to helping eradicate them.
content: Sidney Godfrey was sitting in the passenger seat of a truck slowly cruising over a levee one night in 2018. This far into Florida’s dry season, the air was thick with the smell of mud wafting up from the exposed canals and wetlands along the edge of Biscayne Bay, south of Miami. Mr. Godfrey, a wildlife biologist, kept his gaze — and his headlamp — pointed down to light up the water at the base of the levee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Laing
title: In ‘Organ Meats,’ Best Friends Cling to Each Other Like a Dog Pack
description: The third book by K-Ming Chang is a coming-of-age story mired in body horror, feminism, rot and decay.
content: Say you had a brilliant friend, the Lila to your Lenù, but instead of being separated by education and opportunity, she was kidnapped by a banana ghost and fell into a sleep that lasted a decade. “Organ Meats” possesses something of the febrile intensity of Elena Ferrante’s Neapolitan novels, their laser focus on female friendship, but instead of Naples, K-Ming Chang’s wild girls inhabit a magical universe of talking dogs and shape-shifting body parts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Clare Toeniskoetter, Rob Szypko, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: The Lawyers Now Turning on Trump
description: Two members of the former president’s 2020 legal team pleaded guilty in Georgia, agreeing to cooperate with prosecutors.
content: Over the past few days, two of the lawyers who tried to help former President Donald J. Trump stay in power after losing the 2020 election pleaded guilty in a Georgia racketeering case and have agreed to cooperate with prosecutors against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roland Kielman, Ryan Mercer and Helen Ouyang
title: Stabbed. Kicked. Spit On. Violence in American Hospitals Is Out of Control.
description: Emergency rooms are among the most dangerous workplaces in the United States.
content: Crushing chest pain, an itch that festers into torment, an inconsolable baby, no place to sleep at 3 a.m., an ankle twisted on a jog, a fentanyl overdose, a car crash, the need to tell someone, “I feel sad and lonely.” The only place that tends to this kaleidoscope of needs is the emergency room, its doors perpetually open to all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: New York Has Regained Its Lost Jobs. Why Doesn’t It Feel That Way?
description: Mayor Eric Adams announced last week that the city recovered all of the jobs lost during the pandemic. Analysts say that’s only part of the story.
content: Mayor Eric Adams last week celebrated a milestone in New York’s economic recovery: The city has regained all 946,000 private sector jobs lost during the coronavirus pandemic, more than a year ahead than predicted by the Independent Budget Office, a city watchdog. In total, the city had 4,709,400 public and private jobs in September, the most ever recorded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Is Roz Chast ‘Terrible at Decorating’? You Decide.
description: The New Yorker cartoonist has trouble making decisions about décor. Anyone who has seen the art collection in her home may not notice.
content: For years after she moved to Connecticut from New York, Roz Chast had recurring dreams about her beloved post-college apartment on West 73rd Street. The storyline and set design of those reveries varied, but she was always on the street where she had lived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Why Health Care Workers Are Burning Out
description: A survey by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found that health workers last year experienced significant rates of anxiety and depression.
content: Health workers feel burnout more frequently than they did before the Covid-19 pandemic, while also struggling with symptoms of anxiety and depression, sleep problems and harassment, according to a federal survey of American workers published on Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Nadav Gavrielov
title: 85-Year-Old Held Hostage in Gaza Says She ‘Went Through Hell’
description: Yocheved Lifshitz offered the first public account to emerge from the more than 200 hostages estimated to be held in Gaza.
content: Yocheved Lifshitz, the 85-year-old woman who was released after being held hostage by Palestinian militants in Gaza for 17 days, on Tuesday described being beaten while her captors took her away on a motorcycle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Joseph J. Kohn, Who Broke New Ground in Calculus, Dies at 91
description: The techniques he developed in the field of complex numbers have found use in tackling a wide range of fundamental equations in physics.
content: Joseph J. Kohn, who played a key role in extending the mathematics of calculus, died on Sept. 13 in Plainsboro, N.J. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: G.O.P. Nominates Mike Johnson for Speaker After Spurning Emmer
description: The selection of the low-profile Louisianian capped a topsy-turvy day, but it was not clear that Mr. Johnson could do any better at uniting Republicans and ending the paralysis engulfing the House.
content: Divided House Republicans chose and then quickly repudiated yet another of their nominees for speaker on Tuesday and rushed to name a fourth, prolonging a remarkable three-week-long deadlock that has left Congress leaderless and paralyzed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Our 9th Annual Student Review Contest
description: We invite students to play critic and submit an original review about a recent creative work. Contest runs from Nov. 1 to Dec. 6.
content: Do you like sharing your opinion with others? Do you have strong reactions to books, movies, restaurants or fashion? Are you a foodie or a gamer? A music buff or a theater aficionado?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Covid Shots May Slightly Raise Stroke Risk in the Oldest Recipients
description: A federal study hinted at increased risk when the vaccine was given with the high-dose flu shot, but the research is far from conclusive.
content: The Covid vaccines made by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna may be linked to a slight increase in the risk of stroke when administered along with a high-dose flu vaccine, according to a new analysis by the Food and Drug Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: In Texas, Local Laws to Prevent Travel for Abortions Gain Momentum
description: Lubbock County, home to more than 300,000 near the New Mexico border, has become the fourth and largest Texas county to bar travel assistance for abortions.
content: In recent months, abortion opponents in Texas have succeeded in passing a growing number of local ordinances to prevent people from helping women travel to have abortions in nearby states that still allow the procedure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Jenna Ellis, Former Trump Lawyer, Pleads Guilty in Georgia Election Case
description: Three lawyers indicted with Donald Trump for trying to overturn the 2020 election results will now cooperate with prosecutors in the racketeering case.
content: Jenna Ellis, a pro-Trump lawyer who amplified former President Donald J. Trump’s baseless claims of election fraud as part of what she called a legal “elite strike force team,” pleaded guilty on Tuesday as part of a deal with prosecutors in Georgia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Israel ramps up Gaza strikes.
content: The death toll in Gaza, reported by the Hamas-run health ministry, rose sharply yesterday, after Israel said it had struck hundreds of targets in the territory in one of the biggest barrages of airstrikes in recent days.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Spencer Ackerman and Peter Beinart
description: The Oct. 24, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Spencer Ackerman and Peter Beinart. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Assumptions on Israel and the Palestinians Are Smashed by War
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 24, 2023.
content: “I’m sorry, America, but the Middle East is not done with you. Geopolitical facts cannot be ignored.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: When a Book Deal Feels Like ‘Winning the Middle-Age Lottery’
description: Dann McDorman, the executive producer of “The Beat With Ari Melber,” gave up writing fiction in his 20s. Now, he’s publishing his first novel at age 47.
content: For a few hours every morning, Dann McDorman sits on his windowed front porch in Brooklyn, a steaming cup of coffee by his side, a computer on his lap and maybe a space heater by his feet if it’s cold. There he sits, for an hour or two, writing novels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: quirky
description: This word has appeared in 319 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word quirky has appeared in 319 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 12 in “A Bathtub in the Kitchen? Not a Problem for New Yorkers” by Jess Eng:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham and Jamie Kelter Davis
title: Two Illinois Parishes Live on Either Side of a Catholic Divide
description: As the pope and church leaders meet in Rome to discuss the Roman Catholic Church’s future, they face a chasm between conservatives and progressives in the pews.
content: When the Rev. John Trout heard that Pope Francis wanted feedback from parishes before a major Vatican gathering this month on the church’s future, he decided that his suburban Chicago congregation would go all in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Farnaz Fassihi and Eric Nagourney
title: As Gaza Barrage and Deaths Surge, Angry Accusations Fly at U.N.
description: Israel said it struck more than 400 targets in Gaza in its broadest single-day assault of the conflict. Palestinian officials said more than 700 were killed, the highest one-day toll of the war.
content: Escalating its onslaught against Hamas, Israel hit the Gaza Strip with hundreds of airstrikes in a single day, Israeli officials said Tuesday, and officials in Hamas-controlled Gaza said it was the deadliest day for Palestinians there since the conflict began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu and Cade Metz
title: Cruise’s Driverless Taxi Service in San Francisco Is Suspended
description: California’s Department of Motor Vehicles cited safety concerns for the suspension, about three months after the state allowed an expansion.
content: California regulators on Tuesday ordered Cruise, a General Motors subsidiary, to stop its driverless taxi service in San Francisco after a series of traffic mishaps, including one this month when a Cruise car dragged a pedestrian 20 feet after a crash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Senate Confirms Biden’s Nominee to Lead the F.A.A.
description: Michael G. Whitaker, who received bipartisan support, faces the challenge of stabilizing an agency that had been without a permanent leader for more than a year and a half.
content: The Senate on Tuesday confirmed Michael G. Whitaker, a former Obama administration official, to lead the Federal Aviation Administration, filling a key vacancy that had persisted for more than 18 months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Editor’s note: Tomorrow, Wyna Liu, a Connections editor, will be answering questions in our comments from 2-3 p.m. Eastern time! Ask her how she creates the boards, where she draws inspiration from, how she ended up as a puzzle editor and more. We’ll be taking questions from the comments section.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Alphabet Has Strong Ad Sales but Cloud Business Disappoints
description: Google’s parent company reported that sales were up 11 percent from a year ago while profit jumped 42 percent to $19.7 billion.
content: A rebound in digital advertising led to an uptick in revenue and profit for Alphabet, Google’s parent company, but investors were underwhelmed by its cloud computing business, which badly trails those of rivals Microsoft and Amazon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Currie Jr
title: This Is What Keeps My Eco-Anxiety in Check
description: The simple act of picking up trash, I’ve found, has an outsize effect on my worrying over climate change and ecological catastrophe.
content: From spring until late fall, when winter weather drives me indoors to the treadmill, I spend 20 minutes each morning after my run around the Back Cove in Portland, Maine, walking the shoreline, picking up garbage. Every day is Groundhog Day — I gather plastic cups, syringes, food containers and cigarette butts the same as the morning before, and the same as the morning before that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
title: She Heeded Biden’s Warning to Migrants. Will She Regret It?
description: After surviving a perilous jungle, a mother and daughter obeyed the president’s plea to enter the United States legally. 341 days later, they’re still waiting.
content: They live in a rusty shack with no running water, hiding from the violence just outside their door, haunted by a question that won’t go away: Should they have listened to President Biden?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Dining’s Past Is on the Menu at Clara in the New-York Historical Society
description: Kawabun opens its first branch outside Japan, Altair channels the elements and more restaurant news.
content: The New-York Historical Society, founded in 1804, has gradually upped the ante when it comes to dining. Its Storico, run by Stephen Starr’s organization, closed in July. Next up is the Oberon Group from Brooklyn, where it runs Rucola, Rhodora, June Bar and more, with a focus on sustainability. Diego Moya, the group’s culinary director and a chef who rose to prominence during his pre-Covid stint at Racines, in TriBeCa, is the executive chef here, with Joseph Gaglio as his chef de cuisine. The restaurant takes its name from Clara Driscoll, who was in charge of the women’s glass-cutting department at Tiffany Studios from 1892 to 1909. She designed many Tiffany lamps, some of which are in the museum’s outstanding collection. A few Tiffany pieces and other items from that era fill the shelves that decorate the airy, off-white dining room but, like shards of truffle over pasta, not enough to make a statement. Mr. Moya’s menu has its eye on New York history with a lobster Newburg and a charlotte russe. Other dishes, like winter chicories with green goddess dressing, fluke crudo, carrot tartare, duck breast au poivre, steelhead trout and bay leaf mousse with burnt cranberries, depend on local and regional purveyors. The adjacent Café 77 for salads, sandwiches and other quick-serve items, run by Purslane, Oberon’s catering division, will open in two weeks. (Opens Wednesday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: Five Quick Fall Pastas
description: Think spaghetti tangled with butternut squash and brown butter, orecchiette with brussels sprouts, and cheesy stovetop mac with sausage and kale.
content: Hi, all! Genevieve here, filling in for Emily Weinstein and realizing that almost exactly a year ago, I wrote about how pasta was all I wanted for dinner. Maybe it’s the season — a little chill in the air, a lot of too much going on — that calls for tender noodles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: This Is Your Brain on Crime
description: When perceptions are detached from reality.
content: In 2022, according to F.B.I. numbers, there were 370 violent crimes reported for every 100,000 Americans. Even allowing for some underreporting, this likely means there was less than one violent crime for every 200 people. So the great majority of Americans haven’t been victims lately, or probably ever.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Rolling Stones Played Old! They Played New!
description: Last week the band played an intimate release show in New York celebrating its latest album, “Hackney Diamonds.” Now hear songs from the new LP in conversation with ones from the past.
content: Last Thursday, I had the absurd good fortune of going to Racket — a 650-capacity club in Manhattan that one recent Google review called an “intimate venue, perfect vibe to see a small concert — to see a seven-song set by … the Rolling Stones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Ukrainian ‘Artifacts’ Seized in Spain May Not Be Treasures, Experts Say
description: The Spanish police seized gold pieces believed to be Greco-Scythian artifacts, dating back centuries, and arrested the people selling them. But archaeologists are not so sure of their value.
content: To the police in Spain, the artifacts possessed an ancient and golden allure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: British Freighter Sinks in Fatal North Sea Collision
description: Two cargo vessels collided in a busy shipping lane. At least one mariner is dead and several others are missing.
content: Two cargo ships collided in the North Sea in the early hours of Tuesday morning, sinking one vessel and leaving at least one mariner dead, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Is Pumpkin Good for You?
description: It’s the quintessential flavor of fall. It also has big benefits for your health.
content: Q: Pumpkins are everywhere in the fall. But are they good for me?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Britney Spears Doesn’t Need to Narrate Her Memoir for It to Sing
description: The actor Michelle Williams reads the audiobook version of the recently liberated pop star’s memoir, “The Woman in Me.”
content: At the beginning of the audiobook version of her new memoir, “The Woman in Me,” Britney Spears grabs the mic for exactly 85 seconds. Her speaking role consists of the dedication (“For my boys, who are the loves of my life”), a 163-word prologue and an author’s note that doesn’t appear in print.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laetitia Vancon and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: What It’s Like to Be Young in Ukraine Now
description: Each age group has suffered through the war, but for young adults it has been particularly hard — and not just for those who have served on the frontline.
content: The years of young adulthood are often associated with opening horizons. Making friends. Having adventures. The first independent steps into work, or study, or love. For many young Ukrainians, though, war with Russia has upended that reality, replacing it with danger and death, depression and dislocation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Media Companies Eye Cricket-Loving Diaspora in the U.S.
description: Investors are trying to capitalize on the relatively small — but loyal and growing — audience for the sport.
content: Right after morning prayers on a Saturday this month, members of the Masjid Quba mosque in Brooklyn joined a party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Do You Think Any of These Mythical Creatures Might Be Real?
description: Bigfoot. The Loch Ness monster. Yetis. Could they really exist? Or are they all hoaxes or superstitions?
content: Bigfoot was supposedly sighted again recently, this time wandering a mountainside in southwestern Colorado.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: 13 Law Enforcement Officers Killed in Ambush in Mexico
description: The attack was in the Mexican state of Guerrero, which has been plagued by turf wars between drug cartels.
content: An armed group ambushed and killed more than a dozen law enforcement officers in southwestern Mexico on Monday, including a local security secretary and a police chief, adding to a soaring number of deadly attacks against the police in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Israel Says It Will Destroy Hamas. But Who Will Govern Gaza?
description: Israel has set itself a stiff challenge in aiming to vanquish Hamas. But an even bigger question looms: Once in Gaza, how and when does Israel get out?
content: As Israeli soldiers have massed to enter Gaza in force, the defense minister has promised them, “You see Gaza now from a distance; you will soon see it from inside.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Columbia University Postpones a Fund-Raiser as Divisions Over War Deepen
description: Columbia has said it should be a space for “moral and intellectual conversations” about the Israel-Hamas war, but as those conversations harden, the choice may affect its finances.
content: Columbia University has postponed a major fund-raising drive in the latest sign that on-campus turmoil caused by the Israel-Hamas war is not only testing the limits of free speech on campus, but is also poised to affect the institution’s pocketbook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: Unhappy Animals Languish in Overcrowded Shelters
description: Animal Care Centers of NYC is struggling to find homes for soaring numbers of abandoned pets.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. I’m filling in for James Barron today. We’ll look at why so many dogs are coming into New York City’s animal shelters and how that is affecting the shelter animal population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Energy Agency Sees Peaks in Global Oil, Coal and Gas Demand by 2030
description: The prediction, which has stirred controversy among oil producers, is a sign of a sweeping transformation in the global energy landscape.
content: For more than a century, the world’s appetite for fossil fuels has been expanding relentlessly, as humans have continued burning larger amounts of coal, oil and natural gas almost every year to power homes, cars and factories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Dave Chappelle’s Remarks on Israel Draw Cheers and Walkouts in Boston
description: In apparently unplanned comments, the comedian waded into the Israel-Hamas war and decried the humanitarian crisis in Gaza, provoking strong reactions at a Boston show.
content: Dave Chappelle waded briefly into the Israel-Hamas conflict at a show in Boston last week, drawing cheers from some audience members and causing others to walk out as he decried the humanitarian crisis unfolding at the Gaza Strip, according to news reports and a spokeswoman for the comedian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Traffic Tickets Are No Bar to Owning a Gun in New York City, Judge Rules
description: A federal judge’s decision means that the city may no longer be able to consider people’s moral character when they apply for a firearms license.
content: The New York Police Department wrongly denied a Brooklyn man a firearm license because of his many traffic violations, a federal judge ruled Tuesday, a decision that could stop the city from considering moral character when deciding whether someone can have a gun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Something Wicked This Way Paddles
description: Every October, hundreds of revelers in witch costumes float on lakes and bays, ponds and harbors. Instead of brooms, they opt for paddle boards.
content: At first, the silhouette looked familiar — a person in a pointed hat with a long robe holding a broom-shaped object. But the setting felt out of place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Georgia Supreme Court Allows State’s Six-Week Abortion Ban to Remain in Effect
description: A lower court is now expected to hear arguments on the broader question of whether the right to privacy in the state constitution protects a right to abortion.
content: Georgia’s Supreme Court upheld the state’s prohibition of abortion Tuesday, rejecting arguments made by doctors and advocacy groups that the law was unconstitutional when the state legislature approved it in 2019, more than three years before the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Edwaard Liang Appointed Artistic Director of Washington Ballet
description: Liang, a choreographer who has run BalletMet in Ohio for 10 years, is the first Asian American to lead a ballet company of this size and stature.
content: The Washington Ballet announced on Tuesday that Edwaard Liang would be its next artistic director, starting immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Morgan Freeman Would Like to Tell You the History of Everything
description: In an interview, Freeman discusses narrating the Netflix documentary “Life on Our Planet,” which goes from the dawn of time to the present day.
content: Morgan Freeman’s rich, majestic voice has graced a number of documentaries over the years, about religion, Jewish refugees, even penguins. His next one has a scope and subject that befit a man popularly known as the voice of God: the entire history of life on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Azzopardi
title: ‘Milli Vanilli’ Review: Blame It on the Fame
description: Luke Korem’s documentary retraces the manufactured pop duo’s rise and fall, while asking pertinent questions about the price of stardom.
content: The performers Fab Morvan and Rob Pilatus earn your empathy in the documentary “Milli Vanilli,” a jolting, eye-opening investigation on how fame destroyed them. The war-of-words film, directed by Luke Korem, unfolds like a whodunit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: After a Long Intermission, a New Act for a Flagship Paris Theater
description: The Théâtre de la Ville, now named for Sarah Bernhardt, reopened after a seven-year renovation. But its once-radical approach to dance is now less of a calling card.
content: A lot can happen in seven years. When the Théâtre de la Ville — a flagship venue for Paris’s contemporary dance and theater scene — last welcomed audiences, in late 2016, TikTok had just launched. A pandemic seemed like a far-fetched idea. La(Horde), the influential dance collective featured prominently during the theater’s reopening festivities this month, was still wholly unknown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Latest Figure to Flip in Election Case Had Direct Ties to Trump and Giuliani
description: Jenna Ellis, the lawyer who pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate with the authorities in the Georgia prosecution, was closely involved in efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
content: A few days before the 2020 election was slated to be certified by Congress, the lawyer Jenna Ellis sent President Donald J. Trump a memo suggesting a way he could stay in power by upending the normal course of American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Miss Juneteenth,’ ‘Dredd’ and More Streaming Gems
description: Women in competitions, chaos in high places and documentary portraits of Covid life are among the running themes of this month’s off-the-radar selections on your subscription streaming services.
content: Of all the films that would have been sleeper hits, had they not been released in 2020 when a theatrical push was off the table, it’s hard to top this, the debut feature from the writer and director Channing Godfrey Peoples. Nicole Beharie stars as Turquoise Jones, a Texas single mother whose 15-year-old daughter (Alexis Chikaeze) is about to compete in the local Miss Juneteenth pageant Turquoise won, once upon a time. Peoples’s screenplay sensitively explores poignant questions of opportunities lost and gained, and the mother/daughter dynamics are convincing and compelling. But the real takeaway here is Beharie, whose marvelous, lived-in performance is both inspiring and shattering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: How Columbia Sportswear Is Loosening Its Ties to Asia
description: Confronted with the U.S.-China trade war and disruptions in the shipping industry, the company is shifting some production to Central America.
content: Stan Burton wandered the Guatemalan factory like a prospector probing for buried treasure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hope Reese
title: Feeling Stressed? These 5 Books Can Help.
description: We asked psychologists, counselors and researchers for their recommendations.
content: Too much stress is bad for our health — putting us at risk for conditions like depression, heart disease and memory problems. But life is full of commitments and pressures that make relaxation seem impossible, and finding ways to soothe can be difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: All Eyes on the Rafah Border Crossing
description: The latest from the Israel-Hamas war. Weekday afternoons with Lulu Garcia-Navarro, and Times journalists on the ground.
content: Israel intensified its bombardment of Gaza on Tuesday. As the death toll rose, President Biden said that the pace at which humanitarian aid was getting into Gaza was “not fast enough.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Dr. Donlin Long, Wide-Ranging Medical Innovator, Is Dead at 89
description: A neurosurgeon, he helped develop an insulin pump for diabetes patients and a device to relieve pain, and joined Ben Carson in a historic operation on conjoined infants.
content: Donlin M. Long, a pioneering neurosurgeon whose brain research helped millions of patients manage pain and who collaborated on the invention of an implantable pump to deliver insulin to people with diabetes, died on Sept. 19 near Gettysburg, Pa. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
